author: origami_asshole
body:
Storytime Late July: My dad asked me to buy him Fiserv, I was like “wtf Fiserv, whatever”. Turns out he meant Pfizer. 

Now he’s threatening to kick me out of the house because he got blasted by Fiserv post earnings dump and thought he was holding Pfizer calls for the past two weeks. How do I get his 35k back? The fiserv calls expired last week and I told him yesterday. He was like “WHAT THE FUCK IS FISERV I SAID PFIZER” 

He is legit throwing shit at me right now.

author: BtchesLoveHotTubs
body:
I need some new long ideas. Here’s some that I’ve been reading up on to buy big and stay long on… (I’m not a pro or anything so I’m not saying these picks are 100%, and *constructive* criticism is welcome.)

(SOFI) -  Pretty sure everyone knows sofi… One of my fav fintech stocks that is still very young and is growing very nicely. Seem to be making all the right moves.

(NMTR) - Making worlds first celiac disease drug and also developing a drug for covid treatment. It’s a spec, but imagine this potential.

(DKNG) & (PENN) - Rapidly growing. Will continue to have an expanding TAM as states legalize online gambling & betting. Canada just passed some laws too. Both companies made some recent acquisitions to continue growth and expansion. They have their eyes set on going a lot further than where they are.

(DIS) - Disney is a powerhouse. Their streaming business has been growing and parks will just continue to generate as we move past covid. Streaming, movies, theme parks, cruise lines, merchandise… they have their hands in everything. I think disney’s streaming service is going to be a monster.

(KBWY) - It’s basically a REIT etf. It’s got a high dividend yield. It’s still not fully recovered from pre-pandemic levels. I believe real estate will continue to recover. I’d just keep this forever and keep buying into it over time and let the DRIP grow it too.

(Z) - Zillow got a lot of attention with the housing boom and is taking advantage of it. Apparently they’ve been buying up a TON of real estate. I think that’s a genius idea to streamline real estate transactions. High P/E currently but I think as their new plans unfold that will rapidly make a lot more sense.

(FISV) - Love what they’re doing in the fintech space. They’ve been making a lot of acquisitions to expand their reach and I think they have a good plan to keep making their mark… BUT… not yet. I think their P/E is something like 70-80 so I’d wait for a pullback on this one before starting a position.

$SOFI $NMTR $DKNG $PENN $DIS $KBWY $Z

Share your ideas or tell me what you think about these ones.

Good luck everyone.

author: fuckaliscious
body:
Yes, little fish get eaten by bigger fish that get eaten by huge fish.  Not hard to understand.  It will happen within a few years.  Maybe by STNE or a US based mega sponsor that wants to expand south of the border and into gambling.

The card associations like VISA and MC are a completely different beast, related but separate.. 

Paysafe is a payment processor, so a big player is Square which had operating margins of 4% last quarter.  Another is FISERV operating margin of 7% last quarter.  The payment processors have low margins but make crap tons of $$$ because of their large scale.

Visa is great, a card association but definitely NOT a payment processor.

Nice try though... good luck to you

author: greensymbiote
body:
These are fair concerns. I think the large float is intentional due to the profile of a fintech that already does $100 billion in transactional volume and controls enough market share to be so readily accumulated by institutions. 

Regarding competition, see section on MOAT. They clearly differentiate themselves from competitors in iGaming, eCash, multi-jurisdictional regulatory expertise and risk management.

Debt is currently high but they just had their debt rating upgraded, successfully refinanced all of it at much lower rates and are on track to expand margins and cash flow to reduce leverage. As I posted:

>"The deal synergies and our growth profile will allow us to de-lever quickly and meaningfully make progress in 2022 towards our target of 3.5 times adjusted EBITDA.”  
>  
>This quoted debt/EBITDA ratio is better than most fintechs, including FOUR, RPAY, AFRM, BILL, PAYS and FISV.  Even before they reach that target, the new interest rate of 3.25% indicates that their pro forma free cash flow to debt service ratio will be around 4.5 to 1.

author: greytoc
body:
By what metric are you using?

Square transaction payment volume is about $120Bn...

Fiserv transaction payment volume is over $2.6 trillion...

FIS transaction payment volume is over $1,7 trillion...

And for Fiserv and FIS - payment processing is only a subset of their fintech businesses - such as core banking account processing, etc. 

I don't quite understand what MSFT and AAPL have to do with payment processing.

author: Spac_a_Cac
body:
Only example i know is Betsy Cohen's first SPAC with CardConnect Corp. It was acquired by First Data Corp.(part of Fiserv now), In 2017 for $15 a share about 1 year after merger
Here is the deal
 
Transaction Valuation* Amount of Filing Fee**$557,833,454.78 $64,652.90 *Estimated solely for purposes of calculating the filing fee. This calculation is based on the offer to purchase all of the issued and outstanding shares of common stock, par value $0.001 per share, of CardConnect Corp. (the “Company”), at a purchase price of $15.00 per share, net to the seller in cash, without interest and subject to any required tax withholding. The Transaction Valuation was calculated based on the sum of: (i) 31,472,060 issued and outstanding shares of common stock of the Company, multiplied by $15.00 per share; (ii) 8,105,169 shares of common stock of the Company underlying outstanding options with an exercise price that is less than $15.00 per share, multiplied by $6.77 (rounded up to the nearest cent) per share (which is equal to the difference between $15.00 and $8.23 (rounded down to the nearest cent), the weighted average exercise price of such options that have an exercise price that is less than $15.00 per share); and (iii) 10,300,000 shares of common stock of the Company underlying outstanding warrants, multiplied by $3.00 per share (which is equal to the difference between $15.00 and $12.00, the weighted average exercise price of such warrants), which calculations reflect the maximum number of options and warrants that are expected to be outstanding at the time the offer is completed. The foregoing numbers of shares of common stock, options and warrants have been provided by the issuer to the offeror and are as of the close of business on June 5, 2017, the most recent practicable date.

>It cant be that hard to make a bnpl service if there are so many different ones out there already.   

Product software is incredibly hard. It's not just about building the software, is much, _much_ more than that. I don't think there's _so many_ of these companies either - AFTPY, AFRM, Klarna, and technically PYPL are the major ones I'm aware of. Acquiring a company can be incredibly cheaper with a higher probability of success in regards to entering the market you're trying to get into.  
Maybe they overpaid, but strangely enough the market didn't respond in that way and it'll take awhile to actually say for sure anyway

author: bloodyplonker
body:
Your comment is naive and childish at best. You've provided no reasoning on how disruption could happen. ASML has an utter, total, and complete monopoly on those multi-hundred million dollar precision chip cutting machines. Let me ask you this: what kind of company will have the capital and time to be able to newly invent, produce and manufacture multi-hundred million dollar chip and likely fail multiple times in the process? Why would any company go into that when they could do something else and not have to compete with a monopoly?

Paypal, on the other hand is not a monopoly. They have tons of innovative competitors attacking them from all sides, all verticals of their business, including companies like Square and Affirm.

author: Summebride
body:
There's two schools of thought right now.  One is that PYPL had run too far, too fast, and is heading back to a more fair value.  That, plus increasing competition in payments forms a thesis that PayPal is going below $250 again.  

There's another school that says the drop was a mistake, a knee jerk response to a surprise dip... but that the dip shouldn't have been a surprise because the EBay breakup was a known known, and just happened slightly earlier than expected.  That school also feels that Venmo is a juggernaut so the existence of competition doesn't bother them.

I've had a small position and my thesis was a bit of each, but I held through earnings with the intent to sell if it popped.  That didn't happen so I had to make a new plan.  I still intend to sell, but now I'm looking to do so into strength when people realize the earnings sell off was a bit much.  Murphy's Law may prevent that, as the story that "there's lots of competition" is one that can be told today, whereas "Venmo is crushing it" is a story that will more likely be told in slower quarterly instalments.

author: dmitsuki
body:
They didn't. When I spoke to an Intel product lead around 2012 he told me flat out that Intel, as a company didn't even consider AMD competition. He said that the only focus on the company was fighting companies like Qualcomm. This was obvious with their push of things like Atom. They didn't care about HPC because they didn't see any competition in it. Almost all of the money and research was poured elsewhere because everybody went to them for HPC anyway. Once Ryzen was released, which had obvious buy signals about it at the time, they still didn't give a shit, because first gen wasn't as good as Intels established product. 

Then it got better.

Then it got even better.

Then it got even better.

And at that point it was too late, because Intel had focused all of it's energy trying to make atom processors and things of the like nobody wanted, they could no longer trivially keep up in HPC.
